comments.commentBody: It's funny how republicans only get incensed about religous issues that have the potential to harm the President. Extend unemployment insurance as American Catholic Bishops ask? Not so much.  The President seems to be finally realizing the republicans have no desire for good governance or fair compromise. Let them chew on this now.

The president proved to the nation that he was a wise, level headed statesman.

He avoided giving the hysterically negative GOP another manufactured issue to gin up fear, anger and hate over.

He allowed to Bishops to save face even though their position was indefensible on rational grounds. This was impeccable crises management that produced a win/win situation for both parties since the right to women to free contraception was still affirmed. This was not the time to engage in a theological debate or a church vs state fight that could have cost Obama Catholic votes that he got in'08.

Compared to the obviously histrionic partisan response by the GOP leadership, Obama looked to be clearly more presidential than any of his challengers, who if a photograph emerged of Obama eating a chocolate ice cream cone would accuse him of pursuing a black agenda.

The president in this instance wisely chose to stay above the fray and sought a solution beneficial to all parties without compromising anyone's core principles.

Hopefully voters recognized that in Obama they have a leader who does not seek to profit by maniacally dividing the country and benefit at the expense of ginning up hatred and turmoil among voters.

Compare this to Rick Santorum's claiming election will find religious issues taking precedence over economic ones. How out of touch can a candidate be?

He would have been correct if the meant the moral of income inequality, THE major moral issue in our country.

Religious organizations can't spend millions of dollars to try to create laws like banning same sex marriage and then cry fowl when laws are created that don't fit their dogma. You can't have it both ways and why isn't anyone calling them out on their hypocrisy?

As several people have already mentioned in this debate, if churches (and temples and mosques) are going to be allowed to have a voice in the legislative debate, then they can pay taxes like the rest of us.

So many people commenting don't have a clue about the Catholic Church or the dozens of Catholic Hospitals that serve more patients in the US that any other provider. Indeed, I have no love for the Catholic Church, yet if you know anything about it, you would understand that they take this very seriously, it is considered a mortal sin to use contraceptives, and they have had the same position on this for over forty years. Unlike a lot of churches who change with whatever is popular at the time, the CC does not. Therefore, this is a moral grounding that the president seeks to overturn. And in my mind, this is more about religious liberty than a woman's access to contraceptives. Women can get bcps and abortifacts at the local pharmacy for crying out loud. No one is "denying" them anything at all.

I applaud the president (for once) for coming to a justified compromise for both women and the Catholic Church. Catholic Hospitals provide more charity care than any other institution, public or private in the United States. They didn't check their religious liberties at the door when they decided to serve.
Nice try, but what makes him think that he can possibly please any of these people?

The compromise may be OK... Barry O never should have been in this situation, except that the HHS Sec. Sebelius seemed not to have a clue as to what the blowback would be. Pretty stupid, I say. Look, Obama had to do something since there could have been enough Catholics, say 4 or 5% less than in 2008, might have defected and that could cost him in some states. As it is, he'll probably lose some of those votes. That's what it's about: votes.
On the other hand, even liberal Catholics, who think the anti-contraception stance of the Church is crazy, have been offended by this unnecessary provocation. This brouhaha really brought out the bigots.
Now, lest the bishops think they have won and shown their clout and power, I have news for them: Bishops, get working on changing that contraception "doctrine" AND get back to cleaning up that sex-abuse scandal, and how about screaming about the withdrawal of Catholic agencies from the adoption process, because of a mandate that says they have to consider placing children in households headed by same-sex couples. Remember, bishops, "Humanae Vitae" is not dogma! That can be changed!

Having a hard time understanding what requiring that "insurance companies, and not religious institutions, [to] offer contraceptive coverage at no cost" means. Somebody enlighten me?

How else would a religious institution "offer contraceptive coverage," except by contracting an insurance company? Either way, the institution ends up paying money to an insurance company which offers contraception. Isn't that what they were upset about in the first place?

Seems like this all just comes down to how the insurance company itemizes the bill. Whether they're going to charge "$300, plus $5 for contraceptives," or "$305, plus $0 for contraceptives". But I guess I must be missing something.

This whole controversy is the height of hypocrisy. If 98% of Catholic women use birth control at one time or another what is this about. Is it to prevent Catholic men from using the pill? Or some such ridiculousness. Have Catholics no freedom at all. Do they really wish to see a billion hungry children around the world including the U. S. Sex became so pleasurable and joyful to prevent the extinction of humans in addition to an extremely strong drive so what are Catholics trying to do e except control women.

New Rule - no one who can't get pregnant is allowed to have a say in the birth control issue. Other countries do not have this problem. Perhaps because they are governed by adults. The U. S. contintually embarrasses me with its stupidity - including the (sometimes) childless priests, bishops and cardinals.
Notwithstanding the numerous other issues here, the hypocrisy is overwhelming.  A majority of Catholic women in America use birth control.

I agree, to compromise to the Bishops position is just silly, they lost the fight over birth control many years ago. I was born in the 1950's it was normal for families to consist of 5 to 12 children, has anyone noticed that is no longer the case ( among Catholics) We ALL use birth control now.

Will anyone be forcing Roman Catholic women to use contraceptives just because they're free?  Has anyone considered Orthodox Jewish women who also are not permitted by their religion to use contraceptives?  I guess they will be able decide for themselves, rather than have male clergy members police them.

Why not have every employee of a Catholic affiliated organization declare his/her religion when accepting a job there.  Then mandate that only non-Catholics be provided with contraception coverage under their health insurance policy.  In this way, the church wouldn't have to pay for coverage it doesn't morally believe in for Catholics.  Catholic employees shouldn't be upset because, as Catholics, they know the rules.  Non-Catholics could still take advantage of 21st century health care.
Cathloic Institutions also sell medical insurance coverage. Does this mean they will be forced by the government to provide "free" contraceptives also.

It is difficult to believe the weight given the riled up bishops who have demonstrated their lack of caring for the vulnerable in their congregations, lied or failed to act on knowledge of inappropriate actions perpetrated by their own, and refuse to acknowledge that women's bodies belong to them, not the church.

I assume that no man under their control will have coverage for erectile disorder since that is tampering with reproductive possibilities, or worse sex without the intent of reproduction.

comments.commentBody:
I agree that no government rule should force a religious institution in this country to pay for something that violates their principles. However, no religion or religious group/church or person belonging to or believing in a religious teaching, has the right to impose their religious choice on all the people living in our country, a secular and democratic nation. Even if they manage to do so through political power in the federal government, even if the majority of the people believe it is right. A secular nation respects the rights of the minority as well as the majority, as long as those rights and beliefs do not harm other people who do not agree with them.

So let us be very clear... a secular government in a country of many religions cannot force a church or religion to accept gay marriage, or to support the right of abortion choice, or even to accept membership of all people equally regardless of race or gender or economic level, or sexual preference. However, as a civil authority they should and must support all of the above, civil marriage between same sex partners, the right of abortion choice, and equal access to all public , civil and secular organizations, institutions and privileges, employment etc.

It sounds like Obama's "accommodation" allows the Catholic church a little face-saving and still preserves the insurance coverage for contraceptives. To all who were alarmed at any whiff of compromise, please, let's still re-elect him. The alternatives are REALLY alarming.
Bishops 1, Women 0

Nobody was ever denied access to contraceptives, whether it be on religious or economic grounds. The issue was simply whether people should receive FREE contraceptives.

You may want legalized marijuana (it doesn't hurt the non-user), no-fault insurance, and caps on punitive damage settlements. You may also want all income beyond a comfortable level taxed at 100%. That is your right to dream of such a society.

In the contraceptive debate, the Catholics were loudest and most convenient for the Press to cover, complete with pictures of scowling bishops and praying congregants. But there are other reasonable people who see contraceptives as just another service that has worked its way into the national budget under the twin guises of women's health (how does the Pill promote health...it may in fact promote STDs?) and economics (an avoided preganancy is an avoided delivery...shhhhh, particularly in the poorer precincts).

Why aren't we distributng free condoms...something that would tamp down STDs and put men in the public health game.

Why? Because of stronger lobbying on women's issues. It is why we encourage early detection through mammograms but try to look away from one of cancer's root causes (shhh, again, the birth control pill).

But with the constant return to collapsing inequality at the hands of the state, you most clearly resemble the term attached to you by those who disagree: COMMUNIST.

Government cannot fix all the messes we are making with our "rights".

The president proved to the nation that he was a wise, level headed statesman.

He avoided giving the hysterically negative GOP another manufactured issue to gin up fear, anger and hate over.

He allowed to Bishops to save face even though their position was indefensible on rational grounds. This was impeccable crises management that produced a win/win situation for both parties since the right to women to free contraception was still affirmed. This was not the time to engage in a theological debate or a church vs state fight that could have cost Obama Catholic votes that he got in'08.

Compared to the obviously histrionic partisan response by the GOP leadership, Obama looked to be clearly more presidential than any of his challengers, who if a photograph emerged of Obama eating a chocolate ice cream cone would accuse him of pursuing a black agenda.

The president in this instance wisely chose to stay above the fray and sought a solution beneficial to all parties without compromising anyone's core principles.

Hopefully voters recognized that in Obama they have a leader who does not seek to profit by maniacally dividing the country and benefit at the expense of ginning up hatred and turmoil among voters.

Compare this to Rick Santorum's claiming the election will find religious issues taking precedence over economic ones. How out of touch can a candidate be?

He would have been correct if the meant the moral of income inequality, THE major moral issue in our country.

Katmandu,

You write:

Whether any practicing Catholic should or should not attend confession is a matter for that individual and God. And, a private matter between the Faithful and the clergy.

Try this:

"Whether any woman should or should not use birth control is a matter for that individual and God. And a private matter between herself and her doctor."

As a Catholic, and having grown up under the dictates of Catechism, I feel the Catholic hierarchy need to develop some common sense.   It seems that making the use of “birth control” a sin is irresponsible in today's world and these outraged conservatives are just using this issue to stir up ferment.

I have researched the Constitutional questions at issue. In Employment Div., Dept. of Human Resources of Ore. v. Smith, 494 U.S. 872 (1990), the Supreme Court held that a law that is neutral and of general applicability need not be justified by a compelling interest even if the law has the incidental effect of burdening a particular religious practice. In other words, a law mandating that all employer insurance provide free contraceptive need not be subjected to the usual, stringent, "strict scrutiny" test, even if some employers may object to the law on religious grounds. That's the O's legal precedent.

The Smith holding was questioned, in dicta (not essential to a holding, but merely Justices voicing a point of view - in Church of Lukumi Bab Aye, Inc., v. Hialeah, 605 U.S. 220 (1993). Justice Souter wrote, in a concurrence, that there may be powerful reasons to interpret the Free Exercise Clause as applying to all laws that impact religious exercise, not merely those that seek its prohibition, so that neutrality must be substantive (not inhibit actual religious practice), not merely formal (not directly target religion). Similarly, Justices Blackmun & O'Connor wrote Smith was wrongly decided, "because it ignored the value of religious freedom as an affirmative individual liberty and treated the free exercise clause as no more than an anti-discrimination principle."

Would not be surprised if the Supremes agreed to hear this. Hence the attempt to compromise.

The GOP and the Catholic Church have plans to take this issue to the Supreme Court. With a Catholic packed Court who recently affirmed 9-0 in two recent rulings that the 1st Amendment gives special leeway to religious employers, Obama didn't stand a chance upholding the mandate. This" shift" which insures that women will receive coverage for contraception while "accommodating" the churches tenants strengthens Obama's chances with the courts. From everything I have read I think this is a smart legal maneuver which weakens the churche's case.
The GOP has added contraception to it's Cultural War and anyone concerned with a woman's choice to control her own body needs to get behind Obama on this and stop accusing him of caving. He's done more for women's rights than any President in recent history. I for one plan to work even harder than I did in 08 to insure his re-election. If we don't get behind him, our next Supreme Court appointee could be made by the likes of Santorum or Gingrich. A very very scary thought.
Hey.  As a Quaker, I don't want to pay taxes, some part of which are spent on war.  Can I get me an accommodation?  Or will our government insist on maintaining anti-Quaker religious bigotry?

I don't know about all of you, but I am really tired of Republicans and organized religions telling me how to lead my life. Do they think we need supervision by some supreme authority (Republicans) because we can't be trusted to make important decisions on issues like birth control ourselves?

Who cares that the Catholic Church is against birth control. Birth control is legal for the entire American public. If you run a public hospital, you must offer the full range of legal health care services to the public. Simple. I don't know what there is to compromise about. If the Catholic Church doesn't like it, then it can choose to cater only to Catholics (and lose any medicare/medicaid and other government funding) or get out of the hospital business altogether.

I'd prefer the latter.

I think it is very sad that, even though, for more than 225 years, we've had a separation of church & state, that special (more like "specious") interest groups, including the hypocritical Catholic Church keep sticking their noses into politics and continue to try to bend politicians to their will. Why oh why do lawmakers even consider listening to their so-called "demands", when it's obviously unconstitutional to do so. In fact, if churches ARE engaging in politics, then they ought to be paying their fair share of taxes. If they want to remain tax-exempt, then they must withdraw from this shamless lobbying and their political shenanigans.
So, maybe Obama DID over-reach a little in his attempt at equalizing the medical benefits that workers receive; it is discriminatory for anti-abortion employers to deny medical benefits-if an employee already has them-for an abortion or any other service which these hypocritical right-wing organizations decry.
It is not for specai interest groups that are illegally engaging in politics to do, it's for the voters of America to decide when election day comes about in November. At least Obama's willing to admit a mistake. Bush NEVER admitted to the myriad mistakes he made and those were dealy errors, not merely opinionated ones, Re-elect OBAMA!!!

All of you whiners who are complaining about Obama "caving:"  Please stop!  The Repubs and bishops were itching for a fight and if this isn't settled you know it will be the rallying cry for Mitt or Newt or whoever--they're already running around saying Obama is against religion--why do you want to give them more ammunition that will let them distract voters from the real issue, which is that none of the Repub candidates has any useful ideas except the same old saws.  Do we really need to hear them harping about this?  The only thing Repubs in Congress have done in the past few years is to pass legislation regulating women's bodies.  And whiners, what are you going to do?  Vote for Mitt so that he gets the chance to pick the next Supreme Court justices--with the result of a guaranteed reversal of Roe vs. Wade?  Get real, people!
